document.text: which were never answered and! travelling five and seven miles urg ing the Appomattox ladies to join and help them. They were in formed with an indifferent smile, that they had other important du ties and home affairs claiming their time, and their quarters could be better spent elsewhere than on the dead. In one seuse this is true. We have home duties and try not to neglect them, aud the monev ould be possibly more wisely spent While we do this to honor our dead, we try also to impress npo. the minds of the children of the county, hat the Confederate cause was just .ml right and thatthir fathers were not rebellious traitors and to give them a desire to acquire knowledge of the events of their country, and to teach, them to be patriotic aud proud of their South-land and an cestors. The little knowledge, be ginning here may grow in the minds and hearts of each, and be of great benefit to all. The president of the U. D. C. thought last year of giviug up the charter of the Appo mattox Chapter U. D. C. on account of the ladies lack of interest in this county. She wrote the National l D. C. president, and the Virginia president U. D. C. to that effect, stating she would join a chapter in Lynchburg. Letters from the Va. division, S. C. division and Md. di vision came pouring in not to let Appomattox surrender the second time also sending a list of names of prominent ladies who would join among them, Miss Ruth Early, Mrs. James Garnett, Miss M. Amelia Smith, the piesideut of Va. division U. D. C. and the daughter of ex-Gov Wm. Smith of Va., known as Ex tra Billy. The letter expressed surprise at the Appomattox ladies not caring to join one of the largest organizations m the whole south and living in one of the most his torical counties in the world. It is quite a reflection upon the county. We revised the roll and now have ouly eighteen members lu t they say they intend to keep up the or ganization and to be proud they are U. O C. of Appomattox and we shall be more than pleased if Coal ing will forward us the names ot the ladies desiring to join the IT, D. C. or the Memorial Association or any one reading this would like to become a member of either society please forward their name to Mrs. T. A. Smith, president of the Mem orial Association or Mrs. C. W. Hunter, president of U. D. C. West Appomattox. One prominent aim of the U. D. C. is to gather histori cal facts to help the historians of the U. D. 0. historical committee in collecting war experiences, inci dents and reminiscences of the old soldiers, their wives, daughters or any one who can remember during the Civil war. The U. D. C. es pecially requests, Mrs. T. W. Johns to write up hers and Capt. Johns also Mrs. George Miles, Mrs. A. H. Bocock, Major Flood, Mr. Chap Chilton, Drs. Wm. White and Wm. H. Ahbitt, Mrs. Mary Ann Robert son, Mr. Kirk Hannah and any one who will help us, also send us news paper clippings or Magazines or Journals or anything bearing on the war between the states. This is to help in having a correct history of the south. Please dont think yours will not be of service or interest for it may show up the spirit of the times more than you think. A D a u g h t e r .

document.text: Whether you are a born and bred native of Appomattox or a relative newcomer, each of us is justly proud of our beautiful National Historical Park and the old houses and buildings that are a part of it. However, many people are unaware . of other places of interest in the county that are not so well known or so historically significant, but nevertheless have equal beauty and meaning in the develop ment of our county. One such place is the home of Mr. George H. Shreve and the late Ellie Shreve, of Route 1, Appomattox, located approxi mately 6 miles from Evergreen, The home of Mr. Shreve was built in 1820 and was known as the Captain William Han nahs Plantation. Although it originally contained over 1,000 acres, the land has been sold off until only 303 acres remain. The frame constructed house, painted white with black shutters, is located on a knoll under m ajestic oak trees. English ivy grows in profusion around the base of the trees and native holly trees add their beauty to the lawn and nearby fields. The high ceilings and spacious rooms are a perfect setting for the beautiful antiques which furnish the house. Among the unusual pieces is a table which belonged t 6 the 4 fstftiliy of Patrick Henry. This piece, according to Mr. Shreve, will be left to the Patrick Henry Foundation. The wide polished boards of the entrance hall are the very same ones put there in 1820. In the basement, or cellar as it was known in those days, is a small room within a room, known as the wine cellar. Inside are the racks where the homemade wine was stored arql aged. William Hannah, the original owner, was Captain of the Minute Men during the Civil War. He was also a country .doctor who was instrumental in the formation of Appomattox County in early 1845. Captain Hannah had five sons, John Kirk, William, Jr.,

I understand you to say, said Mr. Mills, that Mr. Brown has been mar red three times? or was It four? I say, replied the deacon, that she was Mr. Browns third wife, while he was her fifth husband. But she was the fourth wife of her second bus. band, and the second wife of her first, so that she -----  Let me see, said the parson, the second wife of her first and thewell, then, three and five are eight, and four are twelve, and two are fourteenIf I get the bang of the thing, MrC.Brown has been married fourteen times, and Mr. Brown was her ----  No, you dont understand. Her second husband was married three times be fore he met her. She had been married -once  How could she be married only -once when he was her second bus hand? Only once before she met him, and when she married him she was his fourth wife, so that whil.- he had had four wives, she had had only ----  Is this Brown y6u are speakin, of? No, no! Brown was her fifth. He had been married twice before. Her second Brown had? I mean Brown, of course. Let me explain. Mrs. Brown, sny, married John, Thomas, Jacob, William and Henry. Thomas married Lulu, Mary Hannah and Susan -----  Before he married. Mrs. Brown or after? Before. Well, then, Brown married Emma and Matilda, and John married Agnes. Agnes died, and John married Mrs Brown. Then John died and Lulu, Mary, Hannah and Susan died and then Thomas married Mrs.Brown Then Thomas died, Jacobs wife died and Williams wife died, and William annexed Mrs. Brown. When William died, Emma and Matilda died, and then Brown married Mrs. Brown. Everybody cr.me to Mrs. Brown, you aee! I see, said Mr. Mills. I think I grasp the facts. Ill go right around to see her. Mrs. Brown was at home. And after alluding to the weather and one or two other topics, Mr. Mills said I am deeply grieved. Mrs. Brown, to hear of your bereavement. It must be very, very terrible, even for a per son who Is so used to It. So used to it. What do you mean, sir? Why, I merely meant to suggest that experience cannot reconcile us to these afflictions. But there is this consolation, dear madamtime dulls the edge of our bitterest grief. You wept for John as If you could not be comforted but you see you ----  John! I do not understand you, Sir. You wept for John, but Thomas came. When Thomas was taken you thought yourself utterly inconsolable but there was Jacobhe brought new joy. When Jacob was wafted to a better land your heart was nearly broken, but William healed Its wounds and when William drifted off into the unknown, Henry assuaged your grief. Perhaps there are other Henrys, Williams and Thomases to whom this blessed duty will fall again. Per haps -----  You are talking very strangely, sir, said Mrs. Brown. Oh, no I merely say that now that John, and Thomas, and Jacob, and William and Henry have been called away to join Susan, and Hannah, and Agnes, and Matilda, and Emma, and Lulu, and Mary, and the rest, there is some hope thatthat ---- Why, Mrs. Brown, what on earth Is the matter? document.text: W are proud of Appomat tox High School. It is true we are out on the suburbs of the county, yet we are near enough to feel that her people are our people. His friendB and relations were glad to welcome Mr. Alex Musgrove, who paid his broth er, Mr. R. E Musgrove, a visit this month. Mr, Harry Jennings was in the village Saturday. Miss Estelle Thornton is vis iting friends in Lynchburg. Mr.W. L. Thornton, with his wife and two little boys, Billy nd Thomas, are visiting their home people. Miss Ida Jennings,Miss Han nah and Miss Mattie Chambers were the guests of Misses Sa rih and Ellie Hamlet last week. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Frank lin and little Christine spent several days with Mr. and Mrs. C. M. Jennings last week. Mr. JVT. Jennings, of Lynch burg, was in the village Sun day. Did any of our readers ever attend a tacky party? If  you haveht, you have missed something. One of our neigh- sors gave the young people the privilege of turning the house topsy turvy and the gecora tions, etc., were e The costumes of the guests were droll, beyond all power of description. Miss Hattie Cham hers, of Red House, plaited her hair and wore an Indian head dress over two long plaits, which hung nearly to the hot tom of her skirt Her waist was decorated with ribbons and laces of various colors, one red sleeve, the other blue an overskirt of flowered paper fell gracefully over a beautiful red calico skirt one white shoe, the other red. Someone r 4 marked that Miss Mattie look ed beautiful. Miss Hannah Jennings wore lace curtains draped over white silk with ribbons and laces of various colorsso be ooming. Miss Mattie Haleys quaint old bonnet, big fan and curious little jacket made her appear too cute for anything. Miss ftarah Hamlet wore lace curtains draped over old rose calico with long train, which she said was awfully in the way until she got used to it. Miss Lena Ford wore white lace waist with green calico skirt and red calico streamers with hose and shoes of every oior of the rainbow. Miss Ellic Hamlet wore a robe of pink domestic calico waist with ribbons, shoddy jewelry and laces. Mr. Will Chambers bad rib bons, laces and flowers to match his crownless hat. Mr. Hamlet Jennings wore knee pants with ruffl s and patches. Mr. Tom Chambers wore a grey suit with red ruffles, patches and odd hose. The tackiest couple won each other, and there was a grand wedding. Mr. Hamlet Jennings and Miss Lena Ford

Like all men that have lived, he had hig faults, over those- I propose to draw the mantle of charity and only speak of his high and noble quali- ties, which shoud be magnified for the benefit of the young just coming upon the stage of action. He was in bis 80 year, 65 of which was spent m connection with the Christian church, truely it may be said of him he gave the riper years of his life to his Masters cause, thus set ting a noble example to the young to seek first the kingdom of God aud emulate his noble example. As a public servant he had filled many position for his county and people  being associated, with Janies Piit- tersoft, Wm. M. Hannah, Kit Moore, Billy Watkins, and others, and the last of the older ones.to leave the stage of action. Since the war he has filled the position of school Trustee, Road Oonimissionsr, Super visor, c., which posts of trust he filled with honor and credit to him self, and was frequently urged by his friends to Buffer his name to be used as representative in the Legis ture, this ho positively refused. As an officer he was zelous of the peo pies interest, but liberality all enfes of real, flhvity. it can be said of- him that he was scrupulously hon est had great admiration and rev erence for the truth, and a perfect contempt for a falsehood, or its author. I remember an incident that came under my observation about ten years ago that will illus trate this point. I was walking with him to the post office, he re ceived a letter that needed prompt attention, he borrowed a 1 stamp from the postmaster and promised to pay for it the first time he came over. The next morning I walked with him to the same office, when within a few yards of the office he suddenly stopped and said, I will have to return home, I have forgot

I then ent Floyd Jones after Cliff I then ent to the fire with uncle and began i save the things looked in trunk old him to get out papers and brimr ver to my house he said he had mie money in tray of trunk he also ad some in bottom of trunk in hi coat pocket, which was rumpled up. He said, I am robbed money was one out of hs pocket no money as found in trunk colored boy. anie, and Aunt Nancy were there made a thorough search for the tracks and other evidence found tracks leading into plowed land tracks showed one person tracks bowed he stooped to fire smoke house measured the trackheres he stickI measureu several tracks ind they were the same. Woolridge id, Suppose we compromise this thing and throw out those smoke ruse tracks and have the other wo there were track- of two other pereons. Here a pair of heavy coaree bro- gan shoes were exhibited and the measure was applied and tested and fitted. The shoes were identified as those of Woolridges. On cross-examination witness ad mitted that Woolridge struck a trail which cirried him up to Dora Gulps after he came back from Appomat tox. We all went up there and measured an iron-sunk heel, about an 11 or 12 shoe l was satisfied there was nothing iu it. It is said you were charged with the burning? 1 have never been accused of this burning, except Cliff accused me of this buruiug, and I would like to in troduce witnesses to show that Cliff charged me with this burning. 1 would like to insist that the witness es b put on the stand to prove this fret. Some years ago there was bit terness between Woolridge and I. Superintendent J. K. Hannah, of Appomattox, said -he dined with E. C. Woolridge and his uaughter at ppomattox. He said Woolridge told him that all the buildings of J. S. Forbes were burned this was the first I had heard of the fire. J. F. Dickerson, an Appomattox School Trustee, testified that Wool ridge told him he wrote the will of the late Mr. Forbes, and when told that he Dickerson bad heard that Charlie Forbes was implicated, Woolridge replied that it v,as not so that Janie had written Charlie and he would be here in a few days. E. C. Spencer testifies  I heard that Charlie Forbes had been mur dered on the 21st March nothing had been done to,find him a party of Forbes, Morgan and myself went up to look for him Mr. B. T. Morgan said Charlie had come back I tried to find him and could not, went to Woolridges farm asked him out. Well, Cliff, wheres Charlie ? Who, Charlie Forbes? I dont know! He didnt have anything to do with the fire I wish I could find him. Ive got a letter I want to show you. He was go nervous he couldnt rend .t. He showed guilt as plain as an man he 3pencer ever saw. Well, Cliff, we have always been friends, and I have an Minpleasant duty to perform. Ill have to take you. All right. Ive been expecting it. Ill go with you. He asked lor time to pnt on his clothes we went iu with him he aBked I suppose you all have a warrant for me ? Cliff, you know me well enough tha I wouldnt come after you with out a warrant. Mrs. Woolridge said, JVhile the buildings were burning my littl boy was erving for Cliff to scratch his back that Charlie Forbes was there that morning he paid his father 9 for guano in the morning and came back that night and got it. We started out Wooldrige told only one of the children good bye told his wife to tell Hal Flood and Sam Ferguson to come on down. Where are you going to carry me ? We talked about Farmville an decided to go there Woolridge said he first heard of the fire the nex morning, and asked why didnt the foolish girl ring the bell. Why didnt you go over there and send your sou to Appomattox ?, 11 said he had a young horse to work denied that he had been writing to Charlie under an assumed name said his postofiice was Wert, a few days ago he had it changed to Forbes said that he had not received nidi from any other office. I have said that I would help lynch the parties who did the burn ing, out had no idea I would ever be caught. I am fifty-seven years old and this disgrace is tough. At Forbes postoffice we fe d. Did yopt say Charlie was withiu four and a-half miles of this place Woolridge answered, Echo an swers where?  Tell me and I will catch him ! This is not the time, he said I will tell Ira Orange where he can catch him At Wilburns bridge he called for paper and peucil and wrote Phone Winston McKiuney to see Joe Harvey at Rose Bower and find out positively about Charlie Forbes, and go on by Goins and Jones old place. Woolridge said in a deep study  Well, there were three of us you have me get the others.

document.text: Three Person Lose Their Live In Xe F orkThey War Children. New York, Special.Three persons were killed and three injured In a fire in the six j story tenement, 74 Forsyth street. The dead j 8re Hannah Liebowltz. 13 years old Amelia Liebowltz, 11 years old Joseph Liebowltz, 6 years old. The injured Simon Liebowltz, 33 years old, father of the dead children Dora Liebowltz, 8 years old Michael Bausebbaum, 68 years old.  The injured persons were burned about I the face and hands whilo making their  escape. None of them are seriously injured. The house in which the lire occurred is a typical Eagt side tenement, four families living on a floor. The smoke had already awakened the tenants by the time the policemen who had discovered the Are entered the hallway, and the Are escape on the front of the build lug was soon crowded with partly dressed men, women and children. The policemen tried to get upstairs through the hallway, but the smoke was so dense that they were driven back. Standing on the top of the iron roll In front of tbe house a policeman aided the people In getting down by that way. On the fourth floor lived the family of Joseph Port. Two of the children, rarah, 16 years old, and Bertha, 13, made their way down tbe rear flre-escapeto the first balcony aud then dropped 13 teet into the yard, where they were imprisoned .until the fence was broken down by the firemen and they were liberated. Liebowltz, who is a mattressmaker, lived on the top floor with his wife, Fannie, eight children, and bis wifes mother, Rebecca Solomon. Their apartments wore already Ailed with smoke. Liebowlta seised hla daughter Dora and tried to get down the Stairway, but the flames drove him baok, burning him and the child. He managed to make bis way out through a window over a plank to the roof of the adjoining building. Vra. Liebowltz followed with Lizale, eight months old. Oloee behind her was her daughter Celia, 17 years old, and her son Nathan, IS, who was carrying his nine-year- old slatar Fannie. The children who lost their lives were overcome by the smoke be fore they could reach the window. When the firemen succeeded ia getting into the top floor they found the bodies of the children. Ail had been suffoonted. but their bodies wero blackened by the flames. The damage to the building wsb about 610,0 0.

document.text: the trick they could do it, also.  Such younjg men need to be informed. The man who succeeds to-day ia business, scholar ship j or politics succeeds because he knows how, and he knows how because he has learned how. He who doe 3 not know how is foreordained to failure. There is no more important question the young man can ask himself than how ho can prepare for life as not to be a castaway not lost in the next world, but shipwrecked in ths. For the ratio between what a nan is and what he can do i 3 a constant ratio. Every man will have all the power he earns, and the power that he has will tell, not because people like it or like him, but because it is power, and as such can keep itself erect without being propped up by a labor union cr heid in its place because it is somebodys son. It follows, then, that the most import ant thing a boy can do is to get ready. It is inspiration to kno.v that every ounce of encr-y put into work in the cariy years is so much distinct guarantee of usefulness in the adult years. And next to getting ready, the father should tell his boy that he must get ready for rough weather. The bey must learn to handle the boat of his own experience if he is not to be driven upon the shallows or into the breakers. As he meets and masters the difficulties that beset him getting out of the harbor of the high school or the college, he is equipping himself for the enemies that will assail him on the high sCas. John, then, here points out the possible ways of getting ready. He asserts that permanent success does not depend upon mood, will of the flesh, or will of man, Let me translate Family, force, fur-  but solely upon God. this into the four Fs nishings, faith. John says first a mans success does not I depend upon his family. Dr. Lyman Ab-  bott has developed this thought rational- l ly That no people are great or good sim- i ply because of their ancestry. The great- I ness of America does not depend primari-  ly upon its Pilgrim history. NTo one would j for a .moment dispute this with him. But j I desire to emphasize this from the domes tic viewpoint. A m  s spiritual success, says John, does not upend upon his fam ily. Then it makes no difference what the family, the Bible lays no stress upon here-  dity. He who says this does not know the  Bible. The Bible lays great stress upon I heredity.. When it writes the life of a I great man it begins with his parents. The foundations of cue generation are in all respects laid in the antecedent generation. In an important sense the boy begins to live when his father begins to live. The child is the parent continued down into a new generation. This is science, and it is I good science. But this is Scripture, and it  is good Scripture. Scripture emphasized heredity long before science was born. Hannah, the mother of Moses Elizabeth, I Mary, Lois and Eunice are all maguificent 1 monuments. The Christian women who would duplicate these glorious sons must first duplicate their matchless mothers. As believers in the Bible we have an in terest in heredity. It is the Gospel expec tation that the children grow up bearing the physical features of tneir parents, so in time they will come to embrace and ex- 1 emplify tbe parents faith. Thats what Timothy did, in whom the great apostle rejoiced so much. Heredity is mighty, but let us not think it is almighty. Heredity gives us tendency, but it gives us noth ing else. The children of good parents take in goodness more easily than the chil dren of bad parents. The children of edu cated parents acquire ideas more easily than those of ignorant parents. The fath er, who for five and twenty years has been saying Two times two are four, I guess Ill make it five, gives to his baby child the tendency to make the same multipli cation, but the child must make the choice before it becomes to him a sin. How I wish that that great sermon of Henry Ward Beeecher on Heredity Influence could be printed as a supplement to our courses  in ethics. That sermon makes men tremble at what they may bequeath to their children. But after all, the grace of God is stronger than the sin -of man. What a man is he chooses to be. Weak ness, tendency are handed down, hut the choice is made by the individual himself. Your spiritual success, young man, does not depend upon your ancestry, your her edity, your fathers habits, or your family. John says no man is safe simply because .of his family. But it does not depend upon your per sonal force, which is a free translation for the New Testament word flesh. It stands for the animal man, not necessarily the bad animal man. It means a strong, vigorous force in the man himself. Now, John says this strong, vigorous force will never give a man his spiritual supremacy. Let me illustrate, rather than debate, the proposition. Noah must have had a strong and vigorous will, but it did not insure him against drunkenness. Samson had a ---------- - . mighty will, but it was no match for the 60 kind as to pray him I dark eyes of Delilah. David, what a clor- 001 and then tako it I ions career in overcoming obstacles! What i way vigor! What power! But in the presence  of his guilty love he was weak and wretched. The Rev. Arthur Diinmerdale, I in that greatest American novel, The I Scarlet Letter, had a mightv will, but he j was lost in the presence of Hester Prynne.  That great Irishman, greater than any I other, who ruled with a rod of iron who 1 took the miserabiy misunderstood prob- I lem of home rule and lifted it into a cen- I tral place in the worlds thought who  thrashed the London Times who wrought I miracles in the House of Commons, and j who lifted William E. Gladstone into the n ------ - office of Prime Minister for the fourth Ml . , 7 , Cause YOU keen I time that man, at the zenith of his pow- toa  T 1 1 want to make .n er Y discovered to have invaded another   _i_ j n man s home and was living in a hidden and illicit way. The people of Great Britain tore him from his throne, trampled ids name in the dust, and witin three mouths he was laid away in his grave with e brok en heart. As the traveler to-day waiks by

document.text: the preceding. Tney were Just emerg ing from the ancient darkness into the later day. God had assigned them leaders whose work it was to lead them into the truth, but they werh slow to follow. Being nomads they appointed wor ship wherever they were. There was no temple, tabernacle or ark. A rude altar erected out of the stones of the ground was their temple. In Jacobs family were found terapliim or house hold gods. Sacrifice still retained the social as pect so that it meant little more than a family gathering at which the local deity was present. However, by this time Jehovah was recognized as the God of the Hebrews. Other acts of worship, such as prayer, vows and dreams were observed. There were very few if any hymns at this time. The law had not been fully compiled, and a limited literature. III. This division introduces us to the Canaanitish state. Great changes took place during .his epoch, because the people of Israel discontinued their nomadic life and settled down in the promised land among tribes of foreign faith. We naturally find that the cho sen people suffered no little contamin ation, of which subsequent history is evidence. Sacred places increased in numbers and the worship of Baal flourished. It seems to be a time of degeneration, for the worship of Jehovah was cor rupted. The ark containing the two tables of stone was transported from one place to another. Images were erected to represent the deity, and the Urim and Thmnmim were employed to ascertain the will of God. Sacrifice was regarded as communion with the deity. The burnt offering seems to havebeen used more than any other. Prayer, vows, visions were still observed, while sorcery was los ing its bold. Having discontinued their wandering life they observed the Sabbath, the feasts of the moon and of harvest. It appears, however, that they were not free from corruption. Music and dancing liad its place, and it is said of David as a later time that he danced. There were hymns, such as the exodus song, the song of De borah and the song of Hannah. Lnjvs were assuming form as the outgrowth of custom. They were not written by Moses, but compiled or formulated by him. IV. The prophetic stage. This pe riod is so called because of the number of prophets who exercised a most wholesome influence on the life of the people. This was done by teaching a more enlightened conception of God. Samuel, David, Elijah, Elisha. Isaiah and Jonah were among those who raised the standard of living. The high placed were still used for the worship of Baal, and at one time the worship of Baal and Jehovah were consolidated. At the time of David the ark of the covenant was taken to Je rusalem, and the temple, was com pleted in the days of Solomon, which produced a more orderly system of worship. Idolatrous practices were not, however, entirely superseded, for we read of golden calves at Bethel and Gilgal. The completion of the temple made the most perfect organization and de velopment of the priesthood impera tive. To this time no distinction was known between church and state, but the division of the monarchy in 075 produced a complete separation. Tlie acts of worship continued about the same as In the preceding period, except that certain restrictions were imposed. Sacrifice was offered to es tablish communion with God. There was some human sacrifice. Praying to God was becoming a pleasure, and vows were made by Nazarites. Ora- les and dreams were regarded tys chan- nels through which Jehovah commu nicated His revelations. Sorcery was practiced against the protests of the prophets. A hymn book was in pro cess of compilation and the priests were compiling law. The attitude of the prophets toward existing conditions will help us to ap preciate our theme and make its ap plication. The prophets considered the high places as detrimental to the religious life of the nation. They maintained that the temple was all they required for the worship of the true God. The prophets insisted upon purity of life among the people of God, espe cially the priests. It appears from the records that the sacred office was not entirely free from corruption. They further insisted upon the true worship of the heart. While admit ting the place of forms, they contend ed that the forms must be spiritual ized.

document.text: the pillows and them knows why gilded Newport is turning the cold shoulder on beauty roses, orchids and gardenias grown in hothouses to go wild over the artificial varieties made in the slums. AU paper flowers thus far used at Newjort have been furnished by the most prominent firm of stationers in New York, with branches in other large cities. Accord, ing to their special agent at Newport, commission is being paid by the firm to one of the three most celebrated co tillion leaders in New York society, but this is supposed to be a dead se cret. It seems cruel that fickle fancy should despoil the poor, honest florist, who is so grateful tor your patronage that be employs the same roses over and over again, but the use of paper flowers will relieve social entertainers of a program that has caused many of them to lose hours of sleep. Paper co tillion favors are already In vogue, and now a man who has the entree to every smart house In the country, but who needs the extra money, is at Newport booming paper flowers. Already the committee In charge of the annual Coachmens ball at Newport has pre pared to imitate fashionable society, and Oddfellows Hall will probably be turned Into a bower of paper roses when Hannah and Dennis have their great spree.Town Topics.

document.text: The marriage of Miss Shelia Marie Macdonald of Cumber land to William Presley Hannah of Farm ville took place at the home of the groom at 2 p.m. on August 6th. The bride is the daughter of Mr. Herbert Allen Macdonald of Washington, D. C. and Mrs. Paul D. Hanuska of Cumber land. The groom is the son of Mrs. John Otis Hannah of Farmville and the late Mi Hannah. Rev. Donald Canady offi ciated at the double ring ceremony. Given in marriage by her father, the bride wore a floor length gown accented with lace and flowers, sweetheart neck line and long sleeves. Her veil was chapel length. She carried a bouquet of yellow and white daisies with butter cups and delfinium flowers. Cyndee Rene Jamerson of Gladstone was maid of honor. Karen -T. Huddleston of Farmville was bridesmaid and Christina Rene Hanuska was flower girl. Paul Duval, Jr. and Christopher Shawn Hanuska were ring bearers. John Fried of Farmville was best man and Gilbert Dennis Macdonald of Cumbërland was usher. Following the ceremony, a reception was held at the home of the groom. . After a wedding trip to Tennessee and North Carolina, the couple will reside in Farmville.

document.text: The Honorable John A. Hannah, assistant secretary of defense for manpower and personnel, Washing ton, D. C., and Roscoe Drummond, Washington bureau chief of the New York Herald Tribune, have been named the two evening speakers for the Institute of Rural Affairs at VPI, July 27-30. Hannahs speech is scheduled for opening sessions Tuesday night July 27, Drummonds for Wednesday night, July 28. Wednesday morning, three sec tions are scheduled. Speakers for one section will include Frank L. Teu ton, Agricultural Research Serv ices, U. S. Department of Agricul ture, Washington, D. C., on New Uses for Farm Products, and Miss Gayle Ueland, marketing economist USDA Extension Service, Washing ton. In another section, the centennial celebration of professional entomo logy will be given top billing, with M. P. Jones, entomologist, USDA Extension Service, and Dr. J. O. Rowell, VPI entomologist, as speak ers. L. B. Dietrick, dean of agricul ture at VPI, also will appear, dis cussing VPIs activities in resource conservation. The third section will be especi ally designed for older rural youth, with Mrs. Polly Hanst, homemaker and writer, Oakland, Md., discuss ing Youths Responsibilities in the World Today. Also featured will be a panel discussion on Understand ing Our World Neighbors, with International Farm Youth Ex change delegates participating. Tak ing part will be Nancy Wickline Botetourt, who visited Switzerland in 1953 Frank Keesling, Loudoun who visited Scotland in 1953 Eva Jo Liskey, Rockingham, who visited Chile in 1952 Jean-Claude Malvesin, Algeria, now visiting Virginia and

document.text: The Cure For Scandal. It is told of Hannah More that she had a good way of managing tale bearers. It is said that whenever she was told anything derogatory of another her invariable reply was  Come, we will go and ask if this be true. The effect was sometimes lu dicrously painful.  The talebearer was taken back, stammered out a qualification, or else begged that no notice might be taken of the state ment. But the good lady was inex orable. Off she took the scandal monger to the scandalized to make inquiry and compare accounts. It is not likely that anybody ever a second time ventured to repeat a gos sipy story to Hannah More, says Modern Women. One would think her method for treatment would be a sure cure for scandal.

document.text: The Charlotte Line Our boys passed the physical examination this is truly grat ifying,-yet this means no ex emption from military service. We trust, though, that ere the training begins peace will be in sight. There is nothing im possible, with God let us pray more earnestly than ever be fore for peace. Mrs. R. W. Paulette was at church Sunday and I saw some beautiful flowers on the ree- trum. Mrs. W. 8. Pugh, of Madi- sonville, with her children passed through the village a fow days ago on her way to visit friends in Campbell. We know something about the pleasure one gets out of a visit from Mrs. Pugh-just like a bit of sunshine in the home. Our village is booming yet two autos here and another coming. I met aunt Patsy this a. m. and I thought she looked wor ried. I asked her what troubled her she said Josh had one of dem ar spells of azmess asthma, las nite an he aint fit for nothing die day I done seed him wid dem spells til I knows he puts on haf on em, jes to make me dig all de ta- ters I jes gwine dig de ice ta- ters I ain gwin tech de Irish taters, dey may rot fur all I keer. I told her I didnt know there were any 4ice taters. She said, Yes, tis, too dese ice tates is hard and white, dey dont ever git mealy, and dey keeps. She went on, wiping her eyes, and I thought she was really grieved about Josh. I stopped a minute as I pass ed and uncle Josh looked so pitiful, as he sat with his. head bowed down I asked him bow he felt. I jes has to sleep out here er settin up in die cheer, when de azmoz gits me, but I is thankful dat I kin do dat, case I done live a long time an de thing hasnt kilt me yet dey say dis doctor at de Red House kin cure any thing, and Patsy she gone ar- ter him now. A prize is offered to public school teachers of Virginia for the best essays on the subject, W hy the United States is at War? Our teachers will sure ly have to put on their think ing caps. And wont they have to be careful not to put them on wrong side out, and bind pan before? If you want the best kind of bachelor cooked dinner, oall at ooou on Messrs. Jesse, Tom and Miller Harvey. The rea son they do not marry is be cause they fear they will have to do all of the cooking. Little folks, I am sorry not to tell you about One Foot, Teddy, Hannah Boots, Buster and the kittens this week, but next time I may tell you how One Foot lost her other-foot, and where the kittens sleep

document.text: Sydney Mountjoy, a well-known young man of Stafford county, aged 22 years, was killed while felling timber. He was cutting down a large tree. The tree in falling caught him beneath and crushed out his life. He is survived by his wife, mother, six brothers and three sisters. Mrs. Dickinson, wife of Hon. M. H. Dickinson, member of the Legislature from Spottsylvania county, died sudden ly of heart disease at her home near Mc Henry. She was a daughter of Michael Robinson, and is survived by her hus band and several children. Rev. J. W. West has organized an anti-saloon league at Falmouth with C. J. Chartters as president and over 100 members. A pig belonging to Hannah Walker, in Stafford county, which was bitten by a supposed mad dog, has developed hy drophobia and died. The same dog bit a number of other dogs, and much ap prehension is felt. The Norfolk Railway and Light Com pany awarded a contract of 100,000 for placing all of its electric lighting wires south of Queen street under ground. Miss Kelley, the daughter of Dr. G. C. Kelley, pastor of Court Street Metho dist Church, Lynchburg, was attacked on Washington street, one of the fash ionable thoroughfares of the city, by a negro, who snatched and made off with her purse. When the lady gave an out cry the negro threatened her with bodily harm. Two other such thefts were re ported to the police, and it is thought the same negro was the assailant in each case. Sweeping changes in railroad rates are contemplated by the State Corpora tion Commission, which has already done much for the people of Virginia since its appointment by Governor Montague. The commission has requested repre sentatives of the following railroads to appear before it March 18 Atlantic Coast Line, Chesapeake and Ohio, Nor folk and Western, Richmond, Freder icksburg and Potomac, Seaboard Air Line, Southern and Washington and Southern Railway. In the notice citing these railroads to appear it is stated that it is the purpose of the commission to put into effect rules prescribing minimum charges in lieu of all rules now in effect on these railroads.
